description: Borrowed from Middle French admirer, from Latin admīror, from ad + mīror (“wonder at”).

verbs.description: admire (third-person singular simple present admires, present participle admiring, simple past and past participle admired)

entries.meaning: (obsolete, transitive) To be amazed at; to view with surprise; to marvel at.
examples: examples rather to be admired than imitated

entries.meaning: (transitive) To regard with wonder and delight.
(transitive) To look upon with an elevated feeling of pleasure, as something which calls out approbation, esteem, love or reverence.
(transitive) To estimate or value highly; to hold in high esteem.
examples: to admire a person of high moral worth
He had always admired the work ethos and family values of his friend.

entries.meaning: (US, dialectal, rare) To be enthusiastic about (doing something); to want or like (to do something). (Sometimes followed by to.)
examples: And I'd admire seeing this creek become a sort of stopping place for geese of one sort and another.
